cip.render.raytrace.interfaces

Interface IRtMaterial

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ADualMaterialTexture, AlphaImage, ATexture, Blinn, Block, Checkerboard, Hall, MapLinear, MapNatural, Outlined, PositionTexture, Ridges, SpheresTexture, Wavy, Whitted

    public interface IRtMaterial
    The interface to a material that can participate well in a ray-traced renderer.
    Since:
    1.0

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods

      Compute the colour of a surface as seen from a specific direction.
      void initSampling(int nSample, @NotNull float[] f1dSample, @Nullable float[] f1dRandom, @NotNull Point2f[] pt2dSample, @Nullable Point2f[] pt2dRandom, @NotNull Point3f[] pt3dSample, @Nullable Point3f[] pt3dRandom)
      Specifies the sampling arrays that should be used for distributed ray-tracing.

    • Method Detail

      • initSampling

        void initSampling(int nSample,
                  @NotNull
                  @NotNull float[] f1dSample,
                  @Nullable
                  @Nullable float[] f1dRandom,
                  @NotNull
                  @NotNull Point2f[] pt2dSample,
                  @Nullable
                  @Nullable Point2f[] pt2dRandom,
                  @NotNull
                  @NotNull Point3f[] pt3dSample,
                  @Nullable
                  @Nullable Point3f[] pt3dRandom)
        Specifies the sampling arrays that should be used for distributed ray-tracing. Materials that do not participate in distributed ray-tracing will normally ignore this function, or, pass the arrays down to child materials which may make use of the sampling arrays. Normally, these are used for normal perturbations for rough surfaces.
        Parameters:
        nSample - The number of sub-samples (over-samples) per pixel.
        f1dSample - (readonly) The 1d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling linear phenomena.
        f1dRandom - (readonly) The 1d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt2dSample - (readonly) The 2d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling area phenomena.
        pt2dRandom - (readonly) The 2d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.
        pt3dSample - (readonly) The 3d sample displacement array. The length of this array will be equal to the number of sub-samples per pixel. This array is for oversampling volume phenomena.
        pt3dRandom - (readonly) The 3d 'jitter' array. No assumptions should be made about the length of this array.

      • getColor

        void getColor(@NotNull
              @NotNull RGBf rgb,
              @NotNull
              @NotNull RayIntersection intersection,
              @NotNull
              @NotNull IRtLight[] lights,
              @NotNull
              @NotNull IRtGeometry[] rtObjects,
              @NotNull
              @NotNull IRtBackground rtBkg,
              int nMaxRecursions,
              int nSample,
              int nRandom)
        Compute the colour of a surface as seen from a specific direction.
        Parameters:
        rgb - (modified) The computed colour at the surface.
        intersection - (readonly) The description of the surface - location, orientation, material, etc.
        lights - (readonly) The light in the scene that may affect the intersection.
        rtObjects - (readonly) The objects in the scene.
        rtBkg - (readonly) The background description.
        nMaxRecursions - The maximum reflections to be followed in computing this colour.
        nSample - The pixel sub-sample index. This is used in distributed ray-tracing to make sure the correct sample displacement is used for samples that are distributed.
        nRandom - The jitter array index..
